results.title: Sprout wings and fly
results.creator_credit: Les Blank, Alice Gerrand, Cece Conway and Flower Films
results.brief_description: A touching tribute to Appalachian culture in the form of a profile of the legendary mountain fiddler, Tommy Jarrell - “I eat when I’m hungry, I drink when I’m dry. If I get to feeling much better I’m going to sprout wings and fly”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Blank, Alice Gerrand, Cece Conway and Flower Films

results.title: Springtime in the Rockies
results.creator_credit: Irving Cummings, William Le Baron and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Betty Grable abandons Broadway fame and takes off for the beautiful Canadian Rockies after she has a falling out with her leading man (John Payne). All manner of complications arise when Payne pursues her with a highly unlikely secretary (Carmen Miranda) in tow. In the Rockies, Grable meets up with a former dance partner (Cesar Romero) and decides to teach philandering Payne a lesson in the art of two-timing. The two women lead the men a merry dance in this colourful musical. Carmen Miranda proves to be a fine comedienne with her fractured English and Grable and Romero set the screen ablaze with some wonderful dance routines. Several hit songs are featured in this tuneful showcase.

results.title: Heaven and earth
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Peter Swain, Lois Bianchi, Educational Broadcasting, Granada Television International, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
Heaven and earth traces the way in which mankind’s earliest ideas of the world emerged - sometimes from imagination, sometimes from scientific observation, often from the need of rulers to know their domains in detail. It looks at the earliest concepts of the world’s shape, from Pythagoras, Eristosthenes, and Ptolomy, whose work was rediscovered as the Renaissance flowered, to the ancient Chinese who developed quite different ideas about the shape of the world. Narrated and introduced by Patrick Stewart.

results.title: Staking a claim
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Lois Bianchi, Simon Berthon, Granada Television International, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
A new continent is discovered and the shape of the world is changed yet again. To begin with, the discovery of America, was merely a step in finding a new route to the east. However with Cortes and his expeditions inland, the Europeans discovered a new civilisation and new riches in the form of gold. The Spanish, Portuguese, English and French exploited this wealth and eventually settled the continent. Meanwhile the Dutch established their empire in the east, and discovered Australia. Mapmaking took a giant step forward with the discovery of longitude.

results.title: Pictures of the invisible
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Mark Anderson, Lois Bianchi, Granada Television International, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
In 1858 the picture of the world was transformed by the Frenchman Nadar who combined the new technologies of hot air ballooning and photography to produce the first reproducible “bird’s eye” view of the world. The technique of aerial photography has had extensive military use, but it has also enabled previously unmapped areas, such as the Himalayas and the Amazon to be accurately mapped. Now aerial mapping has been extended to photography from satellites and computer imaging of data, a process also used to convert radar “photography” of what lies beneath the surface of land and sea into a comprehensible form. Narrated by Patrick Stewart.

results.title: The Shape of the world
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Lois Bianchi, Granada Television International, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: Geography is an ancient impulse, and the techniques people have used to accomplish it have been refined continuously over the centuries. The challenge has spurred brilliantly creative solutions and techniques, which were put to work on behalf of the search for knowledge, for empire, for riches. Narrated by Patrick Stewart.

results.title: Stan and George's new life
results.creator_credit: Brian McKenzie, Margot McDonald and Lea Films
results.brief_description: On turning forty years old, Stan (Paul Chubb) decides to leave his job in his father’s barber shop and start a new life. He finds work in the Public Service, working in the Department of Meteorology. There he meets George (Julie Forsyte), a young country girl who is hoping to find happiness in the big city. They fall in love but Stan’s obsession with the weather, an obsession inherited from his father, threatens their secure future. Stan’s expertise with predicting the weather is too threatening for a Government Department run on a tradition of failure. Funny, compassionate and beautifully shot by cinematographer Ray Argall, “Stan and George’s New Life” continues McKenzie’s exploration of an intimate Australian cinema that faithfully captures the textures of Melbourne’s working-class life. Some of the funniest moments come from observing the daily run-ins and relationships of office life - even the tea-break requires a certain etiquette!

results.title: Stamps: a nation's calling card
results.creator_credit: Donald Connolly, Charlie, Papalios Productions and United States Postal Service
results.brief_description: Since 1847, when stamps in the USA were first used, they have developed into a gallery of events and people important to the country, they have also become a textbook of changing styles of art. The film demonstrates how stamps are produced and claims that annually 28 billion stamps are sold in the USA both for postage and to collectors.

results.title: Stampede
results.creator_credit: Claude Fournier, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Stampede Week in Calgary, with special focus on the main performers of the show, the cowboys and the horses. You see the herds come thundering in, and get to know one cowboy very well as he waits for his ride, He moves from rodeo to rodeo, always trying for the jackpot on the back of a bucking bronco.

results.title: Stamp of approval
results.creator_credit: Raymond Garceau, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A long history of research and development means that agricultural produce has attained a high standard. The government program of testing and surveillance maintains quality control, and gives the world market confidence in Canadian products.
